answers.text: those who serve in close attendance to nobility
to watch, to keep watch, to observe, to be on the lookout for something; to serve, to attend

context: The term samurai originally meant "<a0_0>those who serve in close attendance to nobility<a0_0/>", and was written with a Chinese character (or kanji) that had the same meaning. In Japanese, it was originally recorded in the Nara Period as a verb *samorapu ("<a1_0>to watch, to keep watch, to observe, to be on the lookout for something; to serve, to attend<a1_0/>"), which is believed to be derived from the frequentative form (*morapu 守らふ) of the verb moru (守る, "to watch, to guard, to be on the lookout; to keep, to protect, to take care of, to be in charge of, to have as one's ward"). By the Heian period, this word had developed into the verb saburahu (さぶらふ, "<a2_0>to serve, to attend<a2_0/>"), from which a deverbal noun saburahi (さぶらひ, "<a3_0>servant, attendant<a3_0/>") was later derived, and this noun then yielded samurahi (さむらひ) in <a4_0>the Edo period<a4_0/>. In Japanese literature, there is an early reference to samurai in the Kokinshū (古今集, early 10th century):
